intro: Binghamia versicolor var. lasiacantha, commonly known as the red sandplain lillypilly, is a shrub native to the coastal regions of Western Australia. It is characterized by its dense, leathery foliage and produces clusters of small, fragrant white flowers that transition to pink or red as they mature. The plant thrives in well-drained sandy soils and is adapted to full sun exposure. It is a member of the family Theaceae and is known for its ability to tolerate drought and salt spray. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
